bioghist.p: Samuel Delany, also known as "Chip", was born to a prominent black family in 1942 and raised in Harlem. Delany attended the Dalton School and the Bronx High School of Science. Delany was a published science fiction author by the age of 20. He published nine well-regarded science fiction novels between 1962 and 1968, as well as several prize-winning short stories. His most popular novel, Dhalgren, was published in 1975. His main literary project through the late 1970s and 1980s was the Return to Nevèrÿon series, the overall title of the four volumes and also the title of the fourth and final book. Delany has published several autobiographical/semi-autobiographical accounts of his life as a black and gay writer, including his Hugo award winning autobiography, The Motion of Light in Water. Since 1988, Delany has been a professor at several universities including the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, the University at Buffalo, and Temple University.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials related to Samuel R. Delany. Materials include: typescripts and proofs for several of Delany's books and stories, including "The Tale of Gorgik" and "The Tale of Norema"; books edited by Delany; and articles and interviews by Delany. The collection also includes Delany's correspondence with small press publisher William Bamberger.
